newsitem.title: UK: British Conservatives open key pre-poll conference.
newsitem.headline: British Conservatives open key pre-poll conference.

text.p: Britain's Conservatives open a crucial party conference on Tuesday with their grip on power less sure than at any time since Margaret Thatcher piloted them to a 1979 general election victory.
Rows over Europe are expected to dominate a conference which Prime Minister John Major has said should be the launchpad for a another triumph in the election he must call by next May.
With the party over 20 points adrift of Labour in the polls, and the Conservatives seen by voters as the party of sleaze, Major needs a successful conference to begin the fight back.
But harmony was notably lacking with John Redwood, the right-winger who last year challenged Major for the party leadership, prominent among those rocking the boat.

Redwood, appearing on a BBC television current affairs programme, hesitated when asked whether he would urge voters to back the Conservatives or the tiny Referendum Party which wants a plebiscite on Britain's relations with Brussels.
"I think you have to ask me that nearer the time," he said before adding when pressed: "Of course I will answer. Vote for the Conservative Party."
A further sign of tension was the revelation that legislator James Cran, a strong Eurosceptic, had resigned as an aide to Northern Ireland Secretary Sir Patrick Mayhew.
Party aides said Cran wanted to spent more time in his constituency which he feared may now be a marginal seat.

There is widespread dissatisfaction among the Conservative rank-and-file over Major's attempts to bridge the gap between the Eurosceptic wing of the party and members of parliament more favourable to Brussels.

They are particularly opposed to Major's refusal to rule out British membership of the single currency ahead of the election, saying that a commitment to retain the pound is the one thing that could revive the party's political prospects.
Anti-European sentiment could show itself in the first debate of the conference in which Agriculture Minister Douglas Hogg will defend his handling of the "mad cow" issue.

Traditionally pro-Conservative farmers are angry at plans to slaughter thousands of their cattle to stamp out Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) following scientific evidence that it may be transmissable to humans.

But some believe Hogg's negotiating tactics in Brussels to try to lift a ban on British beef exports and the government's handling of the technical aspects of the cull have made a bad situation even worse.
But it will be the reception given to finance minister Kenneth Clarke when he speaks on Thursday that will reveal most clearly how deep the Euro-divide is in the party.

Clarke is widely seen as the most pro-European member of the cabinet, and recently said it would be "pathetic" for Britain to dither over whether to join a single currency once plans for it have been finalised.
A frosty response to his speech from conference delegates would be seen as a sign they are less interested in winning the next election than in triumphing in the internal party debate on Europe.
